lessons.title: Two Pointers - Array Pair Sum
lessons.description: Find two numbers in sorted array that sum to target using two pointers (O(n) time)
lessons.initialCode:
# Two Pointers: Find pair that sums to target
# TODO: Implement using two pointers

def two_sum(nums, target):
    # TODO: Use two pointers from both ends
    pass

nums = [2, 7, 11, 15]
target = 9
result = two_sum(nums, target)
print(result)
lessons.fullSolution:
def two_sum(nums, target):
    left, right = 0, len(nums) - 1

    while left < right:
        current_sum = nums[left] + nums[right]
        if current_sum == target:
            return [left, right]
        elif current_sum < target:
            left += 1
        else:
            right -= 1

    return [-1, -1]

nums1 = [2, 7, 11, 15]
print("Input: [2,7,11,15], target: 9")
print(f"Output: {two_sum(nums1, 9)}")

nums2 = [1, 2, 3, 4, 6]
print("Input: [1,2,3,4,6], target: 6")
print(f"Output: {two_sum(nums2, 6)}")
lessons.expectedOutput:
Input: [2,7,11,15], target: 9
Output: [0, 1]
Input: [1,2,3,4,6], target: 6
Output: [1, 3]
lessons.tutorial:
Algorithm: Two Pointers

Overview

Find two numbers in sorted array that sum to target using two pointers (O(n) time) This algorithm is frequently asked in FAANG interviews and is essential for solving Array problems. Mastering this technique will help you tackle a wide range of coding challenges.

Key Concepts

  • Core algorithmic principle and when to apply it
  • Common patterns and variations of the technique
  • Edge cases and boundary conditions to consider
  • Optimization strategies for time and space complexity

Implementation Approach

The key insight is to recognize when this algorithm applies. Look for these signals: Array problems characteristics, specific input patterns, and optimization requirements. Always start by understanding the problem constraints.

Code Example

def solve(input_data):
    # Step 1: Initialize data structures
    result = []

    # Step 2: Process input with algorithm
    # Apply core technique here

    # Step 3: Handle edge cases
    if not input_data:
        return []

    # Step 4: Return result
    return result

# Example usage
test_input = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
output = solve(test_input)
print(f"Result: {output}")

Real-World Applications

Google: Search algorithms, graph processing, ranking systems.
Facebook: Social graph traversal, friend recommendations, news feed ranking.
Amazon: Product recommendations, inventory optimization, route planning.
Netflix: Content recommendation, A/B testing, personalization algorithms.

Best Practices

  • Always clarify input constraints (size, range, duplicates allowed?)
  • Start with brute force, then optimize iteratively
  • Draw examples and trace through algorithm manually first
  • Handle edge cases: empty input, single element, all same values
  • Test with small examples before submitting
  • Consider space-time tradeoffs

Common Pitfalls

  • Off-by-one errors in array bounds and loop conditions
  • Not handling duplicate values correctly
  • Integer overflow for large inputs (use long/bigint)
  • Not considering negative numbers or zero
  • Forgetting to sort input when algorithm requires it

Interview Tips

  • Explain your thought process before coding
  • Discuss time/space complexity upfront
  • Mention alternative approaches and tradeoffs
  • Test your code with examples (including edge cases)
  • Optimize only after getting working solution
  • Ask clarifying questions about input constraints

Time & Space Complexity

  • Time Complexity: O(n) time
  • Space Complexity: O(1) space
  • Optimization: Consider trading space for time or vice versa based on constraints

Related Problems

Practice similar problems on LeetCode, HackerRank, and AlgoExpert. Common variations include: modifying constraints, adding additional requirements, or combining with other algorithms. Build muscle memory by solving 10-15 problems using this technique.

lessons.title: Sliding Window - Maximum Sum Subarray
lessons.description: Find maximum sum of k consecutive elements using sliding window technique
lessons.tutorial:
Algorithm Pattern: Sliding Window

Introduction

The sliding window technique optimizes problems involving contiguous subarrays or substrings. Instead of recalculating from scratch for each position (O(nk)), we maintain a window and slide it efficiently (O(n)).

Key Concepts

  • Fixed Window: Window size is constant (this problem)
  • Variable Window: Window size changes based on condition
  • Time Optimization: O(nk) O(n)
  • Space Complexity: O(1) - only store window sum

Algorithm Steps

1. Calculate sum of first k elements (initialize window)
2. Set maxSum = windowSum
3. Slide window right:
   - Remove leftmost element (arr[i-k])
   - Add new rightmost element (arr[i])
   - Update maxSum if current sum is larger
4. Return maxSum

Code Walkthrough

Array: [2, 1, 5, 1, 3, 2], k=3

Initial window: [2, 1, 5]  sum = 8

Slide 1: Remove 2, add 1
Window: [1, 5, 1]  sum = 7

Slide 2: Remove 1, add 3
Window: [5, 1, 3]  sum = 9  MAX

Slide 3: Remove 5, add 2
Window: [1, 3, 2]  sum = 6

Result: 9

Pattern Variations

  • Fixed Window: Max sum, average, product (this problem)
  • Variable Window: Longest substring without repeating chars, min window substring
  • Two Pointer Variation: Subarray sum equals K, longest subarray with sum K

Real-World Applications

Network Traffic Analysis: Calculate moving average of packet sizes over time window.

Stock Trading: Find best N consecutive days for maximum profit.

Data Stream Processing: Real-time metrics over sliding time windows (last 5 minutes).

Interview Companies

  • Amazon: "Maximum Average Subarray" - direct sliding window
  • Microsoft: "Minimum Size Subarray Sum" - variable window
  • Bloomberg: "Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters"
  • Google: "Subarrays with K Different Integers" - advanced sliding window

Time Complexity

  • Brute Force: O(nk) - recalculate sum for each position
  • Sliding Window: O(n) - single pass through array
  • Space: O(1) - only store window sum and max

Common Mistakes

  • Forgetting to handle edge case (arr.length < k)
  • Off-by-one errors in window boundaries
  • Not initializing maxSum correctly (use first window sum, not 0)
  • Calculating sum from scratch each iteration (defeats purpose)

Related Problems

Master sliding window to solve: Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters, Minimum Window Substring, Permutation in String, Fruit Into Baskets, and Max Consecutive Ones III.

lessons.title: Trie Word Search
lessons.description: Implement trie (prefix tree) for word search with insert, search, and startsWith operations. Optimize for prefix matching and autocomplete use cases.
lessons.fullSolution:
// Trie for Word Search
from typing import List, Dict, Set
from collections import deque
import heapq

    class TrieNode:
        Map<Character, TrieNode> children = {}
        isWord = false

    class Trie:
        TrieNode root = new TrieNode()

        void insert(str word):
            TrieNode node = root
            for (char c : word):
                node.children.putIfAbsent(c, new TrieNode())
                node = node.children[c)

            node.isWord = true

        search(str word):
            TrieNode node = root
            for (char c : word):
                if (!node.children in c)) return false
                node = node.children[c)

            return node.isWord

        startsWith(str prefix):
            TrieNode node = root
            for (char c : prefix):
                if (!node.children in c)) return false
                node = node.children[c)

            return true

    def main(str[] args):
        Trie trie = new Trie()
        trie.insert("apple")
        trie.insert("app")

        print("Search 'app': " + trie.search("app"))
        print("Search 'apple': " + trie.search("apple"))
        print("Prefix 'ap': " + trie.startsWith("ap"))
lessons.expectedOutput:
Search 'app': true
Search 'apple': true
Prefix 'ap': true

Single number in [2,2,1]: 1

lessons.title: Dijkstra Algorithm
lessons.description: Implement Dijkstra's shortest path algorithm using priority queue. Find shortest paths from source to all vertices in weighted graph with non-negative edges.
lessons.fullSolution:
// Dijkstra's Shortest Path
from typing import List, Dict, Set
from collections import deque
import heapq

    public static List[int] dijkstra(List[int][] graph, start):
        n = graph.length
        List[int] dist = new int[n]
        Arrays.fill(dist, Integer.MAX_VALUE)
        dist[start] = 0

        PriorityQueue<List[int]> pq = new PriorityQueue<>((a, b) -> a[1] - b[1])
        pq.offer(new List[int]{start, 0})

        while (!pq == []):
            List[int] current = pq.poll()
            node = current[0]
            d = current[1]

            if (d > dist[node]) continue

            for (neighbor = 0 neighbor < n neighbor++):
                if (graph[node][neighbor] > 0):
                    newDist = dist[node] + graph[node][neighbor]
                    if (newDist < dist[neighbor]):
                        dist[neighbor] = newDist
                        pq.offer(new List[int]{neighbor, newDist})

        return dist

    def main(str[] args):
        List[int][] graph =:
            {0, 4, 0, 0, 0},
            {4, 0, 8, 0, 0},
            {0, 8, 0, 7, 9},
            {0, 0, 7, 0, 10},
            {0, 0, 9, 10, 0}

        List[int] distances = dijkstra(graph, 0)
        print("Distances from node 0: " + Arrays.tostr(distances))

lessons.title: SQL Injection Prevention
lessons.description: Learn to prevent SQL injection attacks using parameterized queries and prepared statements
lessons.initialCode:
# SQL Injection Prevention
# VULNERABLE: String formatting
# SAFE: Parameterized queries

def unsafe_query(username):
    # TODO: Show vulnerable query
    pass

def safe_query(username):
    # TODO: Use parameterized query (? or %s)
    pass

attack = "admin' OR '1'='1"
print("UNSAFE:", unsafe_query(attack))
print("SAFE:", safe_query(attack))
lessons.fullSolution:
def unsafe_query(username):
    return f"SELECT * FROM users WHERE username='{username}'"
    # Attack: username = "admin' OR '1'='1"

def safe_query(username):
    # Use parameterized query with ? or %s placeholder
    return "SELECT * FROM users WHERE username=?"
    # Database driver escapes the parameter

attack = "admin' OR '1'='1"

print("SQL Injection Prevention Demo")
print("=" * 40)
print()
print("UNSAFE Query:")
print(unsafe_query(attack))
print("Result: Bypasses authentication!")
print()
print("SAFE Query:")
print(safe_query("admin"))
print(f"Parameter: {attack}")
print("Result: Treats input as literal string")
lessons.expectedOutput:
SQL Injection Prevention Demo
========================================

UNSAFE Query:
SELECT * FROM users WHERE username='admin' OR '1'='1'
Result: Bypasses authentication!

SAFE Query:
SELECT * FROM users WHERE username=?
Parameter: admin' OR '1'='1
Result: Treats input as literal string
lessons.tutorial:
Security: SQL Injection Prevention

Introduction

SQL Injection is #3 in OWASP Top 10. Attackers inject malicious SQL through user inputs to steal data, bypass authentication, or delete databases. Prevention requires parameterized queries.

Attack Example

// VULNERABLE CODE
String query = "SELECT * FROM users WHERE username='" + username + "'";

// ATTACK INPUT
username = "admin' OR '1'='1"

// RESULTING QUERY (bypasses authentication!)
SELECT * FROM users WHERE username='admin' OR '1'='1'

Safe Implementation

// SAFE CODE (Java)
String query = "SELECT * FROM users WHERE username=?";
PreparedStatement pstmt = conn.prepareStatement(query);
pstmt.setString(1, username);

// SAFE CODE (Python)
cursor.execute("SELECT * FROM users WHERE username=?", (username,))

Why Parameterized Queries Work

  • Database driver separates SQL code from data
  • Parameters are escaped automatically
  • Single quotes in input become literal characters
  • No way for attacker to break out of string context

Real-World Breaches

Heartland Payment (2008): SQL injection stole 130M credit cards. Cost: $140M in settlements.

Sony Pictures (2011): SQL injection exposed 1M accounts. Class action lawsuit.

Bobby Tables (xkcd): "Robert'); DROP TABLE students;--" famous comic.

Prevention Techniques

  • PreparedStatement (Java): ALWAYS use for dynamic queries
  • Parameterized queries: Use ? or :name placeholders
  • ORM safety: Hibernate/JPA escape automatically
  • Input validation: Whitelist allowed characters
  • Least privilege: Database user with minimal permissions

Best Practices

  • Never concatenate user input into SQL strings
  • Use ORM frameworks (Hibernate, SQLAlchemy) when possible
  • Whitelist validation for special cases (table names, ORDER BY)
  • Don't expose SQL errors to users (information leakage)
  • Run database with least privilege (read-only where possible)

Interview Tips

  • Explain difference between prepared statements and string concatenation
  • Discuss OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities
  • Mention defense in depth (parameterized queries + input validation + least privilege)
  • Know how to use PreparedStatement in Java, parameterized queries in Python

Attack Input: VULNERABLE Output:
^ Script would execute! SAFE Output:
<script>alert('XSS')</script>
^ Script rendered as text, not executed
lessons.tutorial:
Security: XSS (Cross-Site Scripting) Defense

Introduction

XSS is #7 in OWASP Top 10. Attackers inject malicious scripts into web pages viewed by other users. Can steal cookies, session tokens, or redirect to phishing sites. Prevention requires output encoding and Content Security Policy.

Types of XSS

  • Stored XSS: Malicious script stored in database (e.g., comment with " // If displayed without escaping:
    Check this out!
    // Result: All users viewing this comment send their cookies to attacker!

    Defense #1: Output Encoding

    // Always escape HTML special characters
function escapeHtml(text) {
    return text
        .replace(/&/g, "&")   // &  &
        .replace(//g, ">")    // >  >
        .replace(/"/g, """)  // "  "
        .replace(/'/g, "'")  // '  '
        .replace(/\//g, "/");// /  /
}

// Safe output:
""
becomes
"<script>alert('XSS')</script>"

    Defense #2: Content Security Policy (CSP)

    // HTTP Header to prevent inline scripts
Content-Security-Policy:
  default-src 'self';
  script-src 'self' https://trusted-cdn.com;
  style-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline';
  img-src 'self' data:;

// This blocks:
- Inline

lessons.tutorial:
Security: CSRF Tokens

Overview

Prevent Cross-Site Request Forgery attacks using synchronizer tokens Security is critical for protecting user data, preventing breaches, and maintaining trust. This concept is essential for any production system handling sensitive information.

Key Concepts

  • Understanding the security threat and attack vectors
  • Defense mechanisms and prevention strategies
  • Industry standards and compliance requirements (OWASP, PCI-DSS)
  • Detection and monitoring for security incidents

Implementation Approach

Security must be built into the system from day one, not added as an afterthought. Follow the principle of defense in depth with multiple layers of protection. Regularly audit and update security measures.

Code Example

# Security implementation example
import hashlib
import secrets

class SecurityService:
    def generate_token(self):
        # Cryptographically secure random token
        return secrets.token_urlsafe(32)

    def hash_password(self, password):
        # Use bcrypt or Argon2 in production
        salt = secrets.token_bytes(32)
        hashed = hashlib.pbkdf2_hmac('sha256', password.encode(), salt, 100000)
        return salt + hashed

    def verify_password(self, password, stored_hash):
        salt = stored_hash[:32]
        stored_pwd = stored_hash[32:]
        computed = hashlib.pbkdf2_hmac('sha256', password.encode(), salt, 100000)
        return secrets.compare_digest(stored_pwd, computed)

# Usage
security = SecurityService()
token = security.generate_token()
hashed_pwd = security.hash_password("user_password")
is_valid = security.verify_password("user_password", hashed_pwd)

Real-World Examples

Google: Enforces HTTPS everywhere, uses security keys for 2FA, runs Project Zero.
AWS: IAM for access control, KMS for encryption, automated security patching.
GitHub: Dependabot for vulnerability scanning, signed commits, security advisories.
Stripe: PCI-DSS Level 1 compliant, token-based payments, rate limiting.

Best Practices

  • Never store passwords in plain text - always hash with salt
  • Use parameterized queries to prevent SQL injection
  • Implement rate limiting to prevent brute force attacks
  • Keep dependencies updated to patch known vulnerabilities
  • Enable security headers (CSP, X-Frame-Options, HSTS)
  • Use HTTPS/TLS for all sensitive data transmission
  • Implement proper authentication and authorization
  • Log security events for audit and incident response

Common Pitfalls

  • Using weak or outdated cryptographic algorithms (MD5, SHA1)
  • Hardcoding secrets in source code or configuration files
  • Insufficient input validation allowing injection attacks
  • Missing rate limiting enabling brute force attacks
  • Not encrypting sensitive data at rest and in transit
  • Overly permissive CORS settings exposing APIs

Interview Tips

  • Discuss security threats: XSS, CSRF, SQL injection, DDoS
  • Explain defense mechanisms: input validation, output encoding, rate limiting
  • Mention compliance: GDPR, HIPAA, PCI-DSS requirements
  • Cover authentication: OAuth2, JWT, session management
  • Address encryption: TLS, at-rest encryption, key management
  • Discuss incident response and security monitoring

Security Checklist

  • Authentication: Multi-factor, password complexity, session timeout
  • Authorization: Role-based access control, principle of least privilege
  • Data Protection: Encryption at rest and in transit, secure backups
  • Input/Output: Validate input, encode output, parameterized queries
  • Monitoring: Security logs, intrusion detection, anomaly detection

Further Learning

Study OWASP Top 10 security risks. Practice on HackTheBox and OWASP WebGoat. Read security blogs from Google Project Zero, Krebs on Security. Get certified in security (CEH, CISSP). Follow responsible disclosure when finding vulnerabilities.

        # Use bcrypt or Argon2 in production
        salt = secrets.token_bytes(32)
        hashed = hashlib.pbkdf2_hmac('sha256', password.encode(), salt, 100000)
        return salt + hashed

    def verify_password(self, password, stored_hash):
        salt = stored_hash[:32]
        stored_pwd = stored_hash[32:]
        computed = hashlib.pbkdf2_hmac('sha256', password.encode(), salt, 100000)
        return secrets.compare_digest(stored_pwd, computed)

# Usage
security = SecurityService()
token = security.generate_token()
hashed_pwd = security.hash_password("user_password")
is_valid = security.verify_password("user_password", hashed_pwd)

Real-World Examples

Google: Enforces HTTPS everywhere, uses security keys for 2FA, runs Project Zero.
AWS: IAM for access control, KMS for encryption, automated security patching.
GitHub: Dependabot for vulnerability scanning, signed commits, security advisories.
Stripe: PCI-DSS Level 1 compliant, token-based payments, rate limiting.

Best Practices

  • Never store passwords in plain text - always hash with salt
  • Use parameterized queries to prevent SQL injection
  • Implement rate limiting to prevent brute force attacks
  • Keep dependencies updated to patch known vulnerabilities
  • Enable security headers (CSP, X-Frame-Options, HSTS)
  • Use HTTPS/TLS for all sensitive data transmission
  • Implement proper authentication and authorization
  • Log security events for audit and incident response

Common Pitfalls

  • Using weak or outdated cryptographic algorithms (MD5, SHA1)
  • Hardcoding secrets in source code or configuration files
  • Insufficient input validation allowing injection attacks
  • Missing rate limiting enabling brute force attacks
  • Not encrypting sensitive data at rest and in transit
  • Overly permissive CORS settings exposing APIs

Interview Tips

  • Discuss security threats: XSS, CSRF, SQL injection, DDoS
  • Explain defense mechanisms: input validation, output encoding, rate limiting
  • Mention compliance: GDPR, HIPAA, PCI-DSS requirements
  • Cover authentication: OAuth2, JWT, session management
  • Address encryption: TLS, at-rest encryption, key management
  • Discuss incident response and security monitoring

Security Checklist

  • Authentication: Multi-factor, password complexity, session timeout
  • Authorization: Role-based access control, principle of least privilege
  • Data Protection: Encryption at rest and in transit, secure backups
  • Input/Output: Validate input, encode output, parameterized queries
  • Monitoring: Security logs, intrusion detection, anomaly detection

Further Learning

Study OWASP Top 10 security risks. Practice on HackTheBox and OWASP WebGoat. Read security blogs from Google Project Zero, Krebs on Security. Get certified in security (CEH, CISSP). Follow responsible disclosure when finding vulnerabilities.

lessons.title: Code Review Best Practices
lessons.description: Learn to conduct effective code reviews with constructive feedback and collaboration
lessons.fullSolution:
# ORIGINAL (with issues):
def process_data_old(data):
    for i in range(len(data)):
        item=data[i]
        if item!=None:
            print(item.upper())

# IMPROVED (after code review):
def process_data(data):
    if not data:
        return

    for item in data:        # Pythonic iteration
        if item is not None:  # Use 'is not None'
            print(item.upper())

data = ["apple", "banana", None, "cherry"]

print("Original:")
process_data_old(data)

print("\nImproved:")
process_data(data)

print("\nReview Comments:")
print("1. Use direct iteration instead of range(len())")
print("2. Use 'is not None' instead of '!=None'")
print("3. Add spacing around operators")
print("4. Add input validation")
lessons.expectedOutput:
Original:
APPLE
BANANA
CHERRY

Improved:
APPLE
BANANA
CHERRY

Review Comments:
1. Use enhanced for loop (more readable)
2. Add spacing around operators
3. Add null check on input list
lessons.tutorial:
Professional Skills: Code Review

Overview

Best practices for giving and receiving constructive code feedback These soft skills are just as important as technical ability for career success. Top engineers excel not just at coding, but also at collaboration, communication, and delivering impact in team environments.

Key Concepts

  • Core principles and framework for this skill
  • Common scenarios where this skill is critical
  • Tools and techniques used by industry professionals
  • Metrics for measuring effectiveness and improvement

Practical Approach

Developing this skill requires practice and iteration. Start by observing how senior engineers approach similar situations. Apply the techniques in low-stakes environments first, then gradually increase complexity. Seek feedback regularly and adjust your approach.

Code Review Checklist

# Code Review Checklist
[] Functionality: Does the code do what it's supposed to?
[] Tests: Are there unit tests? Do they cover edge cases?
[] Readability: Is the code easy to understand?
[] Performance: Any obvious performance issues?
[] Security: Any security vulnerabilities?
[] Error Handling: Are errors handled gracefully?
[] Documentation: Are complex parts documented?
[] Style: Does it follow team conventions?

# Example Good Review Comment:
"Nice work! The logic is clear. One suggestion: consider adding
a null check on line 45 before calling user.getName() to prevent
NullPointerException. Also, the function could benefit from a
doc comment explaining the expected input format."

Best Practices

  • Be proactive in seeking opportunities to practice this skill
  • Learn from mistakes and iterate on your approach
  • Seek mentorship from more experienced professionals
  • Document lessons learned for future reference
  • Share knowledge with teammates to strengthen team capability
  • Continuously refine your process based on feedback

Real-World Applications

Google: Code review culture, design docs, tech talks, 20% time.
Amazon: PR/FAQ documents, working backwards, two-pizza teams.
Facebook: Bootcamp training, move fast philosophy, hackathons.
Netflix: Freedom and responsibility, context not control, high talent density.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not investing time to develop soft skills (focusing only on technical)
  • Being overly critical or defensive in feedback situations
  • Poor communication leading to misunderstandings and conflicts
  • Not seeking help when stuck, wasting time on blockers
  • Ignoring team dynamics and only focusing on individual contribution

Career Impact

Soft skills differentiate senior engineers from junior ones. While technical skills get you in the door, soft skills determine how far you progress. Engineers who master communication, collaboration, and leadership advance faster and have greater impact on their organizations.

Interview Tips

  • Prepare stories demonstrating this skill using STAR method (Situation, Task, Action, Result)
  • Highlight collaboration and teamwork in your examples
  • Show growth mindset - discuss how you learned from challenges
  • Ask thoughtful questions about team culture and processes
  • Demonstrate empathy and emotional intelligence

Development Roadmap

  • Beginner: Shadow experienced team members, learn the basics
  • Intermediate: Practice independently, seek regular feedback
  • Advanced: Mentor others, establish team best practices
  • Expert: Drive org-wide initiatives, thought leadership

Further Learning

Read "The Pragmatic Programmer", "Clean Code", "Crucial Conversations". Take courses on communication, leadership, project management. Join communities like Dev.to, Hacker News. Present at meetups and conferences. Find a mentor who excels in these areas.

lessons.title: Writing Technical Documentation
lessons.description: Create clear, comprehensive technical documentation including README, API docs, and architecture guides
lessons.expectedOutput:
'racecar': true
'A man, a plan, a canal: Panama': true
'hello': false
lessons.tutorial:
Soft Skills: Writing Technical Documentation

Introduction

Good documentation is as important as good code. It helps teammates understand your work, reduces onboarding time, and serves as reference for future maintenance. Poor documentation costs companies millions in lost productivity.

Types of Documentation

  • README: Project overview, setup instructions, usage examples
  • API Documentation: Function/method signatures, parameters, return values
  • Architecture Docs: System design, component relationships, data flow
  • Code Comments: Inline explanations for complex logic
  • Runbooks: Operational procedures, troubleshooting guides

README Structure

# Project Name

Brief description (1-2 sentences)

## Features
- Feature 1
- Feature 2

## Installation
```bash
npm install
```

## Usage
```javascript
const result = myFunction();
```

## API Reference
See [API.md](API.md)

## Contributing
See [CONTRIBUTING.md](CONTRIBUTING.md)

## License
MIT

Javadoc Best Practices

/**
 * Brief one-line summary.
 *
 * 
Detailed description with examples, constraints,
 * and edge cases. Use HTML tags for formatting.
 *
 * 
{@code
 * // Code example
 * int result = myMethod(5);
 * }

 *
 * @param name parameter description
 * @return return value description
 * @throws ExceptionType when this is thrown
 * @see RelatedClass#relatedMethod()
 * @since 1.0
 */

Writing Guidelines

  • Audience-Aware: Write for your target reader (junior dev, ops team, customer)
  • Examples First: Show usage before explaining internals
  • Be Concise: Remove unnecessary words, prefer bullet points
  • Keep Updated: Update docs when code changes (CI check)
  • Use Diagrams: Architecture diagrams, sequence diagrams, flowcharts

Real-World Examples

Stripe API Docs: Gold standard. Clear examples, error codes, SDKs in multiple languages. Developers love Stripe partly due to excellent docs.

Kubernetes Docs: Complex system made accessible. Tutorials, concepts, reference guides organized by user journey.

React Docs: Interactive examples, clear API reference, troubleshooting guides.

Documentation Tools

  • Javadoc: Auto-generate HTML from Java comments
  • Sphinx: Python documentation generator
  • Swagger/OpenAPI: API documentation from specs
  • Docusaurus: Facebook's documentation site generator
  • MkDocs: Markdown-based documentation

Common Mistakes

  • Obvious Comments: "// increment i" for i++ (waste of space)
  • Outdated Docs: Worse than no docs (misleads developers)
  • No Examples: Theory without practice is hard to understand
  • Too Technical: Assuming too much knowledge from reader
  • Missing Context: Not explaining "why", only "what"

Interview Relevance

  • Google: Emphasizes clear communication. May ask about documentation strategy
  • Amazon: Leadership principle "Insist on Highest Standards" includes docs
  • Microsoft: Strong documentation culture (Office, Azure, VS Code)

Career Impact

Senior engineers are evaluated on documentation quality. Staff/Principal engineers write design docs, RFCs, and architecture guides. Clear writing accelerates promotion.

Best Practices Checklist

  • README with quick start guide
  • API docs with examples
  • Architecture diagram (C4 model)
  • Troubleshooting section
  • Contributing guidelines
  • Changelog (semantic versioning)
  • License file

lessons.title: Debugging Strategies
lessons.description: Master debugging strategies: use debugger breakpoints, add logging, reproduce bugs, use binary search to isolate issues, and read stack traces effectively.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Discount for $100 at 15%: $15.0
Discount for $10 at 15%: $1.5
Bug fixed: Now returns 1.5 instead of 1 for $10 at 15%
lessons.tutorial:
Professional Skills: Debugging

Overview

Systematic approaches to finding and fixing bugs efficiently These soft skills are just as important as technical ability for career success. Top engineers excel not just at coding, but also at collaboration, communication, and delivering impact in team environments.

Key Concepts

  • Core principles and framework for this skill
  • Common scenarios where this skill is critical
  • Tools and techniques used by industry professionals
  • Metrics for measuring effectiveness and improvement

Practical Approach

Developing this skill requires practice and iteration. Start by observing how senior engineers approach similar situations. Apply the techniques in low-stakes environments first, then gradually increase complexity. Seek feedback regularly and adjust your approach.

Debugging Example

// PROBLEM: Function returns wrong result
public int calculateDiscount(int price, int percent) {{
    return price * percent / 100;  // Bug: integer division
}}

// DEBUGGING STEPS:
// 1. Add print statements
System.out.println("price: " + price + ", percent: " + percent);
System.out.println("result: " + (price * percent / 100));

// 2. Use debugger breakpoint here
int discount = price * percent / 100;  // <-- breakpoint
return discount;

// 3. Test with specific values
calculateDiscount(100, 15);  // Expected: 15, Got: 15 
calculateDiscount(10, 15);   // Expected: 1.5, Got: 1 

// SOLUTION: Use floating point
public double calculateDiscount(int price, int percent) {{
    return price * percent / 100.0;  // Fixed: 100.0 ensures float division
}}

Best Practices

git checkout main
git pull origin main
git checkout -b feature/add-user-auth

# Make changes and commit
git add src/auth/
git commit -m "feat: Add JWT authentication for user login"

# Push and create PR
git push origin feature/add-user-auth

# After code review, merge and cleanup
git checkout main
git pull origin main
git branch -d feature/add-user-auth

# Hotfix Workflow
git checkout main
git checkout -b hotfix/critical-security-patch
# Fix bug, commit, push
git push origin hotfix/critical-security-patch
# Emergency merge after quick review

Professional Skills: Performance Profiling

Overview

Tools and techniques for identifying performance bottlenecks These soft skills are just as important as technical ability for career success. Top engineers excel not just at coding, but also at collaboration, communication, and delivering impact in team environments.

Key Concepts

  • Core principles and framework for this skill
  • Common scenarios where this skill is critical
  • Tools and techniques used by industry professionals
  • Metrics for measuring effectiveness and improvement

Practical Approach

Developing this skill requires practice and iteration. Start by observing how senior engineers approach similar situations. Apply the techniques in low-stakes environments first, then gradually increase complexity. Seek feedback regularly and adjust your approach.

Profiling Example

// Slow function (before profiling)
public List<User> getUsersWithOrders() {{
    List<User> users = userRepository.findAll();
    for (User user : users) {{
        user.setOrders(orderRepository.findByUserId(user.getId())); // N+1 query!
    }}
    return users;
}}

// After profiling with JProfiler/YourKit:
// - Identified N+1 query problem
// - Database calls: 1001 (1 for users + 1000 for each user's orders)
// - Time: 5000ms

// Optimized (after profiling)
public List<User> getUsersWithOrders() {{
    List<User> users = userRepository.findAllWithOrders(); // Single JOIN query
    return users;
}}

// After optimization:
// - Database calls: 1
// - Time: 50ms
// - 100x faster!

Professional Skills: Stack Traces

Overview

Reading and interpreting stack traces to diagnose errors These soft skills are just as important as technical ability for career success. Top engineers excel not just at coding, but also at collaboration, communication, and delivering impact in team environments.

Key Concepts

  • Core principles and framework for this skill
  • Common scenarios where this skill is critical
  • Tools and techniques used by industry professionals
  • Metrics for measuring effectiveness and improvement

Practical Approach

Developing this skill requires practice and iteration. Start by observing how senior engineers approach similar situations. Apply the techniques in low-stakes environments first, then gradually increase complexity. Seek feedback regularly and adjust your approach.

Reading Stack Traces

// Exception Stack Trace Example
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NullPointerException
    at com.example.UserService.getEmail(UserService.java:42)
    at com.example.EmailSender.send(EmailSender.java:18)
    at com.example.Main.main(Main.java:12)

// How to read:
// 1. Start from TOP: NullPointerException
// 2. First line is WHERE: UserService.java line 42
// 3. Follow call chain: Main -> EmailSender -> UserService
// 4. Check line 42 in UserService.java

// Code at UserService.java:42
public String getEmail(User user) {{
    return user.getEmail();  // <-- line 42: user is null!
}}

// Fix: Add null check
public String getEmail(User user) {{
    if (user == null) {{
        throw new IllegalArgumentException("User cannot be null");
    }}
    return user.getEmail();
}}

Overview

Estimating complexity and effort for agile planning These soft skills are just as important as technical ability for career success. Top engineers excel not just at coding, but also at collaboration, communication, and delivering impact in team environments.

  • Core principles and framework for this skill

Practical Approach

Developing this skill requires practice and iteration. Start by observing how senior engineers approach similar situations. Apply the techniques in low-stakes environments first, then gradually increase complexity. Seek feedback regularly and adjust your approach.

Story Point Estimation

# Story Point Scale (Fibonacci)
1 point  = 1-2 hours   (trivial: update button text)
2 points = 2-4 hours   (simple: add form validation)
3 points = 4-8 hours   (moderate: add new API endpoint)
5 points = 1-2 days    (complex: integrate payment gateway)
8 points = 2-3 days    (very complex: build analytics dashboard)
13 points = 1 week+    (epic: redesign authentication system)

# Estimation Meeting Example
Product Owner: "As a user, I want to export my data to PDF"

Team Discussion:
- Similar to CSV export we did? (That was 3 points)
- Need PDF library (+1 complexity)
- Formatting layout (+1 complexity)
- Testing with large datasets (+1 complexity)

Consensus: 5 points

# Velocity Tracking
Sprint 1: Committed 20 points, Completed 18 points
Sprint 2: Committed 22 points, Completed 20 points
Sprint 3: Committed 20 points, Completed 21 points
Average Velocity: 20 points per sprint

Professional Skills: Agile/Scrum

Overview

Agile methodologies, sprints, standups, retrospectives These soft skills are just as important as technical ability for career success. Top engineers excel not just at coding, but also at collaboration, communication, and delivering impact in team environments.

Key Concepts

  • Common scenarios where this skill is critical

Practical Approach

Developing this skill requires practice and iteration. Start by observing how senior engineers approach similar situations. Apply the techniques in low-stakes environments first, then gradually increase complexity. Seek feedback regularly and adjust your approach.

Agile/Scrum Ceremonies

# Sprint Planning (Monday 9am, 2 hours)
Goal: Plan next 2-week sprint
- Review product backlog
- Select stories for sprint
- Break down stories into tasks
- Commit to sprint goal

# Daily Standup (Every day 9:30am, 15 min)
Each team member answers:
1. What did I do yesterday?
2. What will I do today?
3. Any blockers?

Example:
"Yesterday: Finished user auth API
 Today: Starting frontend integration
 Blockers: Need design mockups from UX team"

# Sprint Review (Friday 2pm, 1 hour)
- Demo completed features
- Get stakeholder feedback
- Accept/reject stories

# Sprint Retrospective (Friday 3pm, 1 hour)
What went well?
- Good code reviews
- Fast bug fixes

What can improve?
- Better documentation
- Reduce meeting times

Action items:
[] Write setup guide in README
[] Move standup to Slack async

Development Roadmap

  • Beginner: Shadow experienced team members, learn the basics
  • Intermediate: Practice independently, seek regular feedback
  • Advanced: Mentor others, establish team best practices
  • Expert: Drive org-wide initiatives, thought leadership

Further Learning

Read "The Pragmatic Programmer", "Clean Code", "Crucial Conversations". Take courses on communication, leadership, project management. Join communities like Dev.to, Hacker News. Present at meetups and conferences. Find a mentor who excels in these areas.
